awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Planning Grant The University of Memphis: Center for Electrified and Autonomous Transportation in Agile Freight Supply-Chains (CEATAFS)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will plan the formation of a new Center for Electrified and Autonomous Transportation in Agile Freight Supply Chains (CEATAFS) to research emerging technologies in connected, electrified, and autonomous trucking and freight logistics networks and to help build efficient, safe, agile, and sustainable supply chain systems. Members will be recruited from small high-tech start-ups, large automotive corporations, third-party logistics providers, trucking technology platforms, network communications providers, motor carrier fleets, retail chain-stores, e-commerce pioneers, federal research labs, sea and inland ports, and state transportation departments. These diverse stakeholders would fund and guide CEATAFS's transdisciplinary research, led by faculty members in engineering, business, informatics, and public policy at two university sites. CEATAFS research can help solve major national challenges in road transportation and supply-chains, such as crash deaths and injuries, difficult trucking lifestyle, and logistics logjams that disrupt the economy. Research-based solutions will help four societal groups: drivers and vehicle operators, vulnerable road users, consumers and shippers, and passengers sharing roads with freight. Society can benefit from reduced accidents, emissions, fuel use, and cost of goods transport. Increased lane capacity and extended time operation can improve roadway utilization. Improved work conditions may attract more diverse drivers as the nature and future of work - especially truck driving - will be transformed with new roles for human operators interacting with automated systems. The accelerated deployment of freight mobility solutions can help create new global market opportunities for US industries and strengthen US leadership in supply-chain innovations and autonomous trucking. CEATAFS will also train the next generation of engineers, researchers, and managers in electrified and autonomous systems, especially in the Midwest. Outreach programs to broaden participation in engineering and related fields will engage with local organizations, and launch an autonomous electric vehicle racing competition for youth. Research opportunities for undergraduates will be expanded, including industry internships.
 
CEATAFS will be planned to advance research in freight management, supply chain planning, agile logistics, platooning/caravanning, remotely driven and driverless trucks, long-haul electrification, geofenced and smart infrastructure, and last-mile services. CEATAFS research will help scale up the application of connected, electrified, and autonomous vehicles in the logistics and trucking industries, transforming digitally enabled supply chains and increasing e-commerce efficiency. A two-day planning workshop will be held to engage and attract industry members to further refine the research concepts, establish value propositions, and develop a multidisciplinary research agenda aligned with industry members' innovation and technology interests. Potential topics that CEATAFS may investigate include: (i) autonomous vehicle adoption models and business cases; (ii) operational strategies such as platooning and caravanning; (iii) vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-infrastructure communication systems for efficient autonomous operation; (iv) electrification of long-haul trucking with highly durable fuel-cells and optimal deployment of charging stations; and (v) strategies for overcoming the transportation workforce deficit. Conceptual and operational challenges of deploying electric and autonomous freight transportation systems will be explored by converging knowledge in engineering analysis, behavioral sciences, and business analytics. Significant new knowledge will be generated in interdisciplinary fields such as cooperative multi-agent control, reliability assessment, automotive powertrain design, vehicle design, systems engineering, agile logistics, energy management, human-machine interaction, and vehicle data communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Electrified and Automated Trucking (CEAT) is being formed by the Indiana University - Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) (lead site) and the University of Memphis (UoM) (partner site) to converge and apply knowledge in emerging technologies in connected, electrified, and automated freight trucking and public transport networks to advance agile logistics and mobility for all. CEAT aims to bring together diverse private and public sector stakeholders and academic institutions to conduct interdisciplinary research to accelerate the adoption of automated and electrified systems to transport people and goods efficiently and flexibly.

The outcomes of the Planning Grant period are as follows:

Initial Outreach and Customer Discovery: The CEAT leadership team reached out to industry partners throughout the U.S. and identified prospective industrial advisory board (IAB) members. We interacted with over 150 companies through in-person and online meetings within the commercial transportation space, including logistics, vehicle manufacturers, powertrain, and technology providers, to learn what the industry viewed as the most pressing challenges within the center’s research thrusts of electrification and automation. IUPUI and UoM teams actively engaged large and small businesses, startup companies, government stakeholders, and research organizations as potential IAB members. A website was developed (https://www.ceat-iucrc.com/) to provide comprehensive information about the center.

Planning Meeting: We organized a two-day planning meeting in March 2023 at IUPUI involving nearly 30 prospective IAB members to identify the industry needs, discuss the research feasibility, and align the research thrusts with their strategic interests. The meeting included academic researchers from various disciplines, NSF program managers, and industry representatives. The meeting provided a platform for the industry representatives to gather and discuss, identify, and debate critical problems and common issues faced by the industry and some potential solutions. Despite the inclement weather conditions affecting travel plans for a few registered representatives, the overall in-person attendance for the meeting remained strong. A series of online panel meetings were conducted over three days after the planning meeting to accommodate industry members who couldn’t attend the in-person planning meeting.

The faculty researchers proposed eleven research projects covering the center’s research thrusts and presented them to the industry representatives, followed by a question-and-answer session and industry feedback. The industry participants were provided with executive summaries, PowerPoint presentations, and short video presentations on the Airtable platform. After each presentation, the industry participants provided valuable feedback through the live Airtable platform. Industry breakout sessions were organized to facilitate industry discussions without CEAT members present, allowing attendees to discuss their insights, the industry’s broad research needs and challenges and provide feedback on the proposed projects. The industry participants appeared highly appreciative of the opportunity to engage with their peers and academic researchers and expressed enthusiasm for future discussions and follow-up sessions.

The CEAT faculty team engaged in thoughtful discussions, sparking a lively exchange of ideas among the participants, uncovering additional significant challenges the industry faces, and actively seeking solutions. The faculty team took this feedback and promised to incorporate the new input into an updated value proposition for the industry sector. A poster session was held that evening with undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers and the PIs and Co-PIs presenting their proposed and ongoing research. Currently, twenty industry partners have shown strong intent, and twelve members are committed to supporting the CEAT center and forming IAB. These partners will further refine the vision and mission of the center and define the scope of the research projects portfolio of the center.

The Phase I proposal was submitted for NSF review as a significant outcome of the planning grant and with the required industry members’ support.

Intellectual Merit: CEAT will advance research in freight transport planning, supply chain management, agile logistics, platooning/caravanning, remotely assisted truck operations, long-haul electrification, transit electrification, smart infrastructure, and last-mile services. CEAT will integrate knowledge from various disciplines, including engineering, behavioral sciences, and business analytics, to tackle the technological and operational challenges associated with deploying electric and automated freight and public transportation systems.

Broader Impacts: CEAT will train the nation’s next-generation engineers, researchers, and managers, offering technical and business training. To promote diversity, equity, and inclusion, CEAT will collaborate with local organizations and launch outreach programs targeting women and underrepresented minorities. CEAT plans to engage K-12 students by introducing an automated electric vehicle racing competition. Undergraduates will have access to leadership and innovation opportunities. CEAT’s research will address transportation safety, labor, mobility, and reliability challenges, benefiting four key societal groups: drivers and vehicle operators, vulnerable road users, consumers and shippers, and passengers sharing roads with freight. Society will benefit from reduced accidents, emissions, fuel use, and transport costs. Safer and inclusive work environments can attract diverse workers, including women, increasing industry representation and opportunities. Accelerated deployment of freight mobility solutions will help create new market opportunities for U.S. industries and strengthen U.S. global leadership.
